programme.title: The Champion Within
programme.sub-title: Going for Gold: Down But Never Out
programme.desc: Host Lauren Thompson gets us ready for the upcoming Olympic Games. We first meet Megan Blunk, the fearless leader of the U.S. wheelchair basketball team who is making sure her message gets outside the locker room. Then we hear the heroic story of veteran Rick Morales, who was brought home from overseas, but not without struggles. There is one sport where he can find solace, peace and courage to continue fighting.(n)

programme.sub-title: Odometer Fraud Shakedown?; Police Ignore Black Men in Atlanta

programme.title: The Young and the Restless
programme.desc: An iconic, enduring soap opera, this is the steamer set in Genoa City, where the Newman and Abbott dynasties stir it up in the bedroom and the boardroom. Best known for long-term love triangles, issue-oriented plots, a multi-ethnic cast and slick production values, 'Y&R' has been showered with Emmys, launched countless careers and spawned the equally lavish 'The Bold and the Beautiful.' Former cast members include Tom Selleck and David Hasselhoff.(n)

programme.title: The Talk
programme.desc: A weekday gabfest offering a female perspective on the day's headlines and other trending topics, including family, pop culture and health. Celebrity guests are interviewed and music artists perform.(n)

programme.title: Dr. Phil
programme.desc: The life strategist offers advice on a wide range of topics, including marital, financial and self-image issues.(n)

programme.title: Judge Judy
programme.sub-title: Father Reports Suspected Child Abuse; Pit Bull Bites Man in Behind
programme.desc: When a child has scratches and bruises, a concerned father calls DCS on his son's mother, but she says his claims were malicious. Also, a pit bull owner insists that a man's attempts to punch and kick her dog were met with aggressive behavior by her pet.(n)

programme.title: Judge Judy
programme.sub-title: Your Homelessness Is Not Your Sister's Problem; Invasion of Privacy Assault and Theft
programme.desc: A woman and her family move in with her sister and then sue her for credit card charges; a man's 'nanny cam' allegedly captures his roommate stealing his toiletries; he also accuses him of breaking into his room and beating him up.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: Card Sharks
programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Classic Concentration
programme.desc: Two contestants must face a computer-generated board of 25 squares.(n)

programme.title: Family Feud
programme.desc: Two families of five try to guess what the 'survey said' in polls conducted with 100 people in this durable game show. Ray Combs took over as the host of this version from 1988-94, and original emcee Richard Dawson returned for one season in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Classic Concentration
programme.desc: Two contestants must face a computer-generated board of 25 squares.(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled 'Password Plus' and 'Super Password.'.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a 'cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Classic Concentration
programme.desc: Two contestants must face a computer-generated board of 25 squares.(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled 'Password Plus' and 'Super Password.'.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a 'cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Card Sharks
programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Classic Concentration
programme.desc: Two contestants must face a computer-generated board of 25 squares.(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled 'Password Plus' and 'Super Password.'.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a 'cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Card Sharks
programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Match Game

This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: Card Sharks
programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Classic Concentration
programme.desc: Two contestants must face a computer-generated board of 25 squares.(n)

programme.title: Family Feud
programme.desc: Two families of five try to guess what the 'survey said' in polls conducted with 100 people in this durable game show. Ray Combs took over as the host of this version from 1988-94, and original emcee Richard Dawson returned for one season in 1994.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Family Feud
programme.desc: Two families of five try to guess what the 'survey said' in polls conducted with 100 people in this durable game show. Ray Combs took over as the host of this version from 1988-94, and original emcee Richard Dawson returned for one season in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Classic Concentration
programme.desc: Two contestants must face a computer-generated board of 25 squares.(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled 'Password Plus' and 'Super Password.'.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a 'cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Card Sharks
programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: A Navy culinary specialist visiting her family's 100-year-old restaurant in the French Quarter is the target of an explosion. Elsewhere, Brody tracks a lead in the general leak case in Washington, DC.(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: The sisters use a spell to hide Leo from the Angel of Death, but it causes everyone to look like Leo. Elsewhere, Phoebe and Billie search for Billie's missing sister and cross paths with the demon Wietz, a magical big game hunter who holds his victims in suspended animation as trophies.(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: As Billie investigates another theory behind her sister's disappearance, her emotionally distant parents arrive for a visit, and the mild-mannered pair are accidently transformed into cold-blooded killers. Meanwhile, Piper is reluctant to leave the house for fear of leaving her children without a parent in the wake of Leo's absence.(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: Billie's obsession with finding her sister comes back to haunt her---and Paige---when a demon she tortured endangers Henry's life. Meanwhile, Wyatt's third birthday party has some unusual guests: three action figures the toddler brought to life.(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: As Phoebe completes her move out of the Halliwell house, Paige decides it's time to let Henry know of her magical secret and Piper struggles to deal with Leo's absence. But their personal issues are overshadowed by a mysterious demon trio who are hatching a scheme to steal the power of the Charmed Ones.(n)

programme.title: The Goldbergs
programme.desc: Lainey asks Erica for help teaching Barry to be more secure in their relationship, but ends up with a boyfriend who's dressed like Boy George at school. Meanwhile, Beverly's dislike of Murray's new mustache drives her to shave it off, which doesn't turn out the way she hoped.(n)

programme.title: The Goldbergs
programme.desc: Adam chooses to spend Halloween night with Dana rather than Beverly, who decides to teach her son a lesson about the dangers of the holiday. And later, Adam regrets taking Barry and Erica's advice to visit a haunted house when he's expected to go back inside to find Dana's lost promise ring.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Ross faces an ethical dilemma when he must decide whether to tell a patient's grandfather that he missed a bone tumour on his grandson's X-ray four months earlier. Meanwhile, Chloe wants custody of Susie.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: On Greene's fourth straight night on graveyard shift, he leads a skeleton crew through what becomes "the O'Hare of emergency rooms", overflowing with patients, including a battered woman who almost killed her husband.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Ross treats a traumatised 8-year-old who witnessed his mother's murder; Carter uses deception to get a chance to perform a surgical procedure instead of Harper's more surgically experienced college friend; Greene goes on a date.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Lewis throws herself into her work to deal with the loss of Suzie. Meanwhile, Shep becomes more violent on the job; Ross gets closer to Karen while his father's away; and Greene and Jen decide to bypass the lawyers in their divorce.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Lewis visits a therapist to help her sort through her emotions in the wake of a personal tragedy; Hathaway must decide whether to lie to help Shep avoid possible disciplinary action for his violent on-the-job behaviour; Jeanie receives devastating news.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: In the second season finale, Carter prepares for graduation but gets sidetracked when he comforts a frightened patient; Greene bargains with Weaver to approve Lewis as chief resident; Jeanie delivers Benton some potentially devastating news.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: An ailing Princeton-Plainsboro pathologist doesn't trust any of his colleagues to diagnose and treat him, except for House?who's missing. So House's team must make the sceptical patient believe that House is actually directing his case.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: Thirteen returns as the team takes on the case of a college student who suffers a mysterious nosebleed during cheerleading practice. His problems could be both physiological and psychological. Meanwhile, Foreman tries a different approach with House.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: After eight seasons, the series concludes with House treating an ailing drug addict. This leads him to sift through his life, speculate on his future and explore his personal demons.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: In the series pilot, a 29-year-old kindergarten teacher suffers from mysterious seizures that no one on Dr Greg House's diagnostic-medicine team can explain.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 16-year-old boy has night terrors after getting hit on the head by a lacrosse ball, and House immediately suspects he's a victim of sexual abuse. Later, he changes the diagnosis to MS, and that night the youth disappears from his hospital bed. In the clinic, House treats a baby whose mother has an aversion to inoculation, and a man with an infected knee who's almost as obnoxious as House is.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: House sees two infants in the neonatal ICU and determines immediately that an infection is spreading through the hospital. He's right, of course, but what caused it? House's approach is Solomonic, in a way. Meanwhile, one of House's clinic patients is a young woman who has what he calls a "parasite".(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: At Christmastime, a nun arrives at the clinic with symptoms resembling stigmata, and House's initial treatment (for an allergic reaction) nearly kills her. Subsequent efforts don't work either, and lead to much soul-searching. Meanwhile, House has a highly unusual remedy for a man with an inflamed bowel.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: The team partners with Homeland Security for the investigation of a Navy master diver's murder after learning the death could be linked to a foreign attack on the city.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: In the second-season finale, the team exposes a spy and massive security breach while partnering with Homeland Security on a mission to locate 900 pounds of missing explosives.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: In the third-season premiere, the team join forces with other federal agencies to track down a sniper targeting crowded areas of the city. Meanwhile, an FBI special agent begins investigating Pride and the NCIS team.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: Pride faces backlash from the FBI after helping a former Navy intelligence analyst who is the prime suspect in a multiple-homicide case.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: The murder of a decorated petty officer inside a sports arena leads the team to discover evidence linking the crime to the kidnapping of another petty officer who was last seen in Mexico.(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: On the eve of the Chinese New Year, Piper and Billie receive a sign they think will help them return Leo. Instead, they find and disrupt a demon battle with the guardians of the Chinese zodiac, and Piper is charged with protecting their mystical staff.(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: Billie and the Charmed Ones deal with Christy's return, while a surprise suitor appears to ask for Paige's hand in marriage and Piper runs into an old flame---literally. Meanwhile, demons plot to recapture Christy, and put their plan into motion while the sisters are distracted.(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: Paige and Henry reconsider their engagement as Piper plans a party for them; Phoebe realises she is being watched by a strange man; and Christy is kidnapped by a demon.(n)

programme.title: Charmed

Piper is confident she can handle the situation, but the demons are more powerful than she anticipated. Meanwhile, Billie persuades Christy to finally meet their parents; and Coop teaches Phoebe to love again.(n)

programme.title: The Goldbergs
programme.desc: Barry's dream of having a dog comes true, but he's disappointed when the pup takes an immediate liking to Murray; at the same time, Beverly is upset not to be included when Erica and Lainey plan a girls-only sleepover.(n)

programme.title: The Goldbergs
programme.desc: Beverly insists on hosting a big family gathering for Thanksgiving, but tension builds when brother-in-law Marvin tricks Pop-Pop into thinking the Turkey Day celebration is elsewhere. Meanwhile, Barry and Erica turn the traditional holiday toast into a game of one-upmanship.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: In the third season premiere, Carter reports for the first day of his residency and receives a daunting assignment: to replace Benton as the ER's surgical consultant. Meanwhile, Benton and Jeanie get the results of their HIV tests.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: The staff nervously awaits the county's decision on which area hospital will permanently close its doors. Meanwhile, a new chief of staff comes aboard and threatens to make life unbearable for everyone.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Anspaugh makes life hellish for everyone by implementing patient quotas for each doctor; Benton and Jeanie square off concerning her HIV status and whether she should continue to work; Greene is befuddled by Lewis's invitation to go on a joint vacation.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: A one-night stand turns tragic when Ross picks up a woman at a bar and she suffers a seizure. Meanwhile, Benton visits an old flame and Jeanie finds herself attracted to a patient's handsome friend.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: On Halloween night, an 8-year-old girl and her dad fight for their lives after being involved in a hit-and-run accident. Meanwhile, Ross and Hathaway get a jolt of life on the streets when they man the roving Health Mobile.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Greene and Lewis help rescue a family involved in a traffic accident, only to have the tragedy escalate when the victims arrive at County General, due to an insolent nurse and an overconfident Benton, who suffers his most devastating experience as a surgeon.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 38-year-old mentally ill woman has a pulmonary embolism, something a 38-year-old shouldn't have. This intrigues House, so much that he actually wants to meet her (not just treat her condition). Knowing the woman's reality all too well is her teen, who supports her much more than she supports him.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 31-year-old woman sleeps 18 hours a day, and when she's awake she's irritable. It isn't depression, but it will be fatal if House doesn't figure out what it is.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: Something poisoned a high-school student who became ill during a calculus exam, and House and his team must figure out what it was, while battling the young man's mother, who doesn't trust any of them. In the clinic, meanwhile, House admits an older woman for tests because of a personality change: She's suddenly very interested in sex.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A jazz musician, who's already paralyzed from the waist down, collapses at a recording session (which features a cameo by Brandy). His LA doctor is treating him for ALS, and he signs a "do not resuscitate" order. But that's not about to stop House. Meanwhile, that doctor offers Foreman a job.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A homeless Jane Doe collapses while confronting police at an all-night rave, then has a seizure in the hospital. She turns out to be a talented cartoonist, who's diabetic and has a twitch. Wilson suspects ovarian cancer, and Foreman thinks she's faking. House, of course, has another view. He also has another audience: two medical students, who are learning to take case histories.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 16-year-old boy starts bleeding just before the car crash that lands him in the hospital, and the symptoms add up to nothing but a likely death. Meanwhile, Cuddy suggests an unorthodox approach to get House off his painkillers. He takes her up on it and what follows isn't likely to be pleasant for anybody.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A major-league pitcher with a history of drug abuse develops brittle bones. Steroids could be the cause, but he insists he's clean, and tests back him up. He doesn't appear to have cancer, either. And in the clinic, House treats, if that's the word for it, five patients in three minutes. Meanwhile, Foreman is seeing an attractive drug rep, and House and Cameron share a social evening: They attend a monster-truck rally.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 12-year-old who says he's cursed collapses after developing pneumonia-like symptoms and a rash. He had been hanging out in a dusty attic and had scraped his arm. And none of the doctors are pleased to be around the sick boy's very rich and very demanding father. Meanwhile, Chase's father, an eminent rheumatologist, arrives from Australia, but Chase is not at all happy to see him.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: The team must rescue Sebastian after he's abducted from a restaurant and forced to orchestrate a prison break using his gaming skills.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: The team join forces with the FBI to investigate a plane crash in the bayou that left three sailors dead. Meanwhile, Sonja and Lasalle interview candidates for the open agent position.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: A Navy Seal candidate who was murdered just before his graduation leads the team to investigate unorthodox training exercises. Meanwhile, Wade asks Pride for advice after her adopted son announces his own plan to join the Navy.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: The team investigate a sailor's murder during a motorcycle rally in the city. Elsewhere, Lasalle seeks advice on his personal life from Gregorio.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: Pride takes temporary custody of a victim's nephew who witnessed the murder of his aunt, a petty officer and member of the US Navy Band.(n)

programme.desc: Paige and Piper confront a demon who may have answers concerning Leo, but Christy interferes and is injured. Meanwhile, Coop continues to work on Phoebe's love problem, while Paige thinks she may love Henry too much.(n)

programme.desc: Billie is still unsure about fighting the Charmed Ones, so Christy and the demons set out to turn the magical community against the three sisters to prove they must be stopped.(n)

programme.desc: The Charmed Ones are forced to make unusual alliances when preparing for the final battle. Meanwhile, Billie and Christy hope to gain an advantage by tapping into the power of a forbidden artifact, but its effects are unpredictable.(n)

programme.title: The Goldbergs
programme.desc: Barry joins the Army ROTC program after seeing the movie "Top Gun". Meanwhile, Pops enlists Adam's help catching the eye of a certain librarian.(n)

programme.desc: Disappointed with her unenthusiastic family during the holidays, Beverly creates "Super Hanukkah" to get them into the spirit, but it's too similar to Christmas. Meanwhile, Adam is annoyed that Barry is more interested in hanging with Lainey than him, so he triple-dog dares his brother with results neither one see coming.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Benton tries to save a young gang member who has already been pronounced dead by Ross. Meanwhile, Greene suspects that Lewis is dating Morgenstern, and Carter becomes involved in a surprising relationship.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Lewis prepares to leave for Phoenix, while Greene struggles with whether to tell her how he feels; Doyle becomes outraged at a pregnant woman who tried to kill her unborn baby; and Al surprises Jeanie with an unexpected act of kindness.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.sub-title: Ask Me No Questions I'll Tell You No Lies
programme.desc: Greene makes life miserable for everyone with his new no-nonsense leadership style, and goes into Jeanie's private file to learn whether she's HIV-positive, which leads to a volatile confrontation. Meanwhile, Keaton surprises Carter with her travelling plans.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Greene and Weaver try to hammer out a policy concerning workers with HIV, as rumours fly over which staff member tested positive for the disease; Charlie brings in a critically ill baby she's caring for and Ross has an explosive run-in with the child's mother.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Greene puts his job on the line when he treats a mentally incompetent woman without her consent; Gant seeks help from Anspaugh after Benton publicly berates him; Charlie arrives in the hospital and accuses Ross of abusing her.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Carter and Benton exchange heated words in the aftermath of a tragedy and Ross learns some surprising information about Charlie's past. Meanwhile, Hathaway must deal with a nurses walkout.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: While House treats a 32-year-old cosmetics CEO whose leg pain turns much more serious, the hospital welcomes its new board chairman. He's donated $100 million to the Princeton-Plainsboro, and now wants to run it. Not surprisingly, he isn't happy with House or his department.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A mobster about to enter the Witness Protection Program collapses before testifying. His coma doesn't last long, but there's something seriously wrong with his liver. Meanwhile, Vogler leans on Cuddy to fire House while House tries to find out who ratted him out to Vogler about his lie to the transplant committee. And in the clinic, House must deal with a 2-year-old who keeps getting things stuck up his nose.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: Vogler is forcing House to fire one member of his team. Which one? He lets them fight it out as they struggle to save an obese 10-year-old who had a heart attack. Meanwhile, a woman with a huge belly won't hear of it when House tells her she's pregnant.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: Vogler offers House a way out of his personnel problem. Meanwhile, a senator with presidential ambitions doesn't believe it when House tells him he has AIDS. programme.title: House
programme.desc: It's payback time for Vogler after House's speech, leading to boardroom sessions that would make Donald Trump blanch. But House is focused on his patients: a pregnant 39-year-old who has trouble swallowing; and a low-weight baby whose parents have been feeding her a vegan diet. According to social-services authorities that constitutes child abuse.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: During a meningitis outbreak that fills the hospital, a 12-year-old diver exhibits many of the disease's symptoms, and some other ones, too. Meanwhile, with Vogler out of the picture, House offers Cameron her job back.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: Cameron returns on one condition---that House goes on a date with her. In the clinic, meanwhile, House berates a young man, who then has a stroke that will be the first of many. Also, House plays romantic referee to a seventy something couple.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: Sela Ward guest stars as House's former girlfriend, a one-time lawyer at the hospital, who wants House to figure out what's ailing her husband. Meanwhile, the dour doc is persuaded to teach a med-school diagnostics course, and his lecture is illustrated with fantasy sequences.(n)

programme.desc: Prue is targeted by a sleep researcher known as the dream sorcerer, who kills women who spurn him by invading their dreams; Piper and Phoebe cast a love spell.(n)

programme.desc: Moira receives some unexpected news and David makes a tough decision about where he wants to live.(n)

programme.desc: Pride and the team reunite with conspiracy journalist Oliver Crane after the source for his latest vigilante story is murdered. Also, Hannah's former partner, Liam Somers, surprises her in New Orleans and shares a shocking revelation about an old case.(n)

programme.desc: The team investigates multiple murders tied to a construction company creating an experimental chemical that strengthens sea walls. Also, evidence from Hannah's previous mission in Oman is used against her as blackmail.(n)

programme.desc: An elusive terrorist with a personal vendetta against Hannah resurfaces, so she is placed in protective custody with her family while the NCIS team searches for the suspect's whereabouts.(n)

programme.desc: The NCIS team investigates the murder of Patton's friend, a former Navy Seal gunned down in a drive-by shooting while Patton helplessly watched.(n)

programme.desc: The team must fix a pinched gas line in order to prevent a massive explosion after a powerful earthquake hits Los Angeles.(n)

programme.desc: Team Scorpion must stop an influx of drugs that are being smuggled into the country by drones. Meanwhile, Walter gives Happy and Toby an ultimatum on their new relationship.(n)

programme.title: Scorpion
programme.desc: Sylvester competes on "The Price is Right". Later, the team must infiltrate a high-end car-smuggling operation that's preparing to ship bioweapons to South America.(n)

programme.desc: After Los Angeles' blood supply gets hacked and is deemed unusable, the team must find the perpetrator in order to save the life of a young girl in need of a heart transplant.(n)

programme.desc: The team must save Cabe after he's captured during a secret mission in Djibouti, Africa.(n)

programme.desc: The team's mission to recover the remains of marines in Vietnam is compromised when they find themselves in the path of a dangerous tornado.(n)

programme.title: Scorpion
programme.desc: The Department of Defense hires the team to break into Fort Knox and steal an artifact in order to test their security system, but they must force entry once again when they discover something dangerous hidden inside the object.(n)

programme.title: Scorpion
programme.desc: The team travels to Chernobyl to repair a decaying nuclear reactor before a major meltdown occurs, but they must overcome yet another obstacle when Sylvester and Paige become trapped inside.(n)

programme.title: Scorpion
programme.desc: In the second-season finale, a mentally unstable ex-member of Scorpion kidnaps Toby and threatens to kill him unless the team meets his demands.(n)

programme.title: Scorpion
programme.desc: In the third-season premiere, anonymous hackers target major cities after taking control of US military aircrafts and warships.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: A cold case is reopened after a Navy issued stolen gun is found to belong to a chief petty officer who died 40 years ago. The case is personal for Wade, who has personally tracked and investigated it for years. Meanwhile, the team prepare for their annual Thanksgiving dinner.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: The NCIS team investigate the murder of a retired Navy SEAL who tracked down people impersonating military personnel. programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: The NCIS team investigate a deadly explosion at the Navy-Marine Relief Gala and discover Pride was the intended target of the bombing.(n)

programme.desc: The NCIS team partner with the Coast Guard Investigative Service to probe a double homicide aboard a research boat, when an Admiral's daughter becomes the prime suspect in the case. Meanwhile, Lasalle tracks down his estranged brother.(n)

programme.desc: Pride and the NCIS team hurry to solve the impending murder of a Navy Lieutenant who's been poisoned with a lethal dose of radiation.(n)

programme.desc: An NCIS agent is killed during a security detail for the Vice Chief of Naval Operations. Meanwhile, Brody is placed under investigation and her furtive past is reevaluated.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: A Petty Officer is murdered during Mardi Gras, and the team investigates which parades and parties may have led to his death. Meanwhile, Pride struggles to decide which aspects of his strained relationship with his father he is willing to share with his daughter.(n)

programme.desc: A Navy recruiter is killed when she becomes the target of a deadly hit and run. Meanwhile, Lasalle grows increasingly concerned for his brother's welfare after welcoming him into his home.(n)

programme.title: Scorpion
programme.desc: Computer genius Walter O'Brien and his equally brilliant friends investigate high-tech crimes. In the series opener, Walter and his misfit colleagues are hired by the government to solve a crisis at the Los Angeles airport that leaves dozens of planes unable to land.(n)

programme.title: Scorpion
programme.desc: The governor calls on Team Scorpion when his daughter is mysteriously "bio-hacked" with a deadly virus and only has 24 hours to live. Meanwhile, the case takes on a deeper significance for Walter after he receives a letter regarding his sister.(n)

programme.title: Scorpion
programme.desc: A bomb strike threatens the Internet infrastructure for the entire Southwest. Meanwhile, Team Scorpion fails a military training operation and becomes determined to prove themselves.(n)

programme.title: Scorpion
programme.desc: Team Scorpion go to Las Vegas for a simple casino job, but a robbery leads to Walter's arrest, leaving his colleagues to try and clear his name.(n)

programme.title: Scorpion
programme.desc: Walter enlists the help of a former troubled team member when a Los Angeles nuclear reactor is on the verge of a cataclysmic meltdown.(n)

programme.desc: Team Scorpion must pass a mandated psych evaluation or face being disbanded after they are accused of destroying a priceless work of art. Meanwhile, Ralph is reluctant to go to his school's Halloween party, so Paige asks the team to step in and help.(n)

programme.desc: Three convicts break out of prison and the investigation reveals that one of the escapees is a brilliant hacker who is being forced to help the other two steal billions of dollars online. Meanwhile, Paige tries to manage expectations for Ralph when his father returns.(n)

programme.desc: Beverly wants to remodel their kitchen like the Kremps, but Murray isn't willing to do the makeover, and so Bev devises a plan to do the work herself and do it in a way that forces Mur to fix it. Except this scheme doesn't go as smoothly as expected.(n)

programme.desc: Adam and Emmy are excited when their favourite TV game show "Double Dare" holds auditions at their school. programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Benton refuses to seek help following Gant's death, despite a growing listlessness that becomes apparent to everyone, especially Carter, who confronts him. Meanwhile, Greene and Weaver each shepherd a trio of prospective interns through the ER.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Greene sets up dates with three women for the same night; Ross ponders whether to honour a 17-year-old's wish to not be resuscitated; Benton complains of abdominal pains and is whisked into surgery.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Hathaway and seven others are held hostage by two thugs following a botched robbery attempt of a convenience store that leaves two people critically wounded.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Greene and Doyle try to persuade an unyielding Pomerantz to place a woman with Down syndrome on the heart-transplant list; Fischer shocks Jeanie with a surprising request; and an 18-year-old with cystic fibrosis asks Ross to take him off life support.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Two teen gunshot victims, one white, one black, arrive in the ER, and Greene is accused of being racially biased in his treatment by one of the victim's brothers. Meanwhile, Carla, six months pregnant, comes in for treatment after being in a minor car accident.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Benton goes into Carla's private hospital files when he fears that something may be wrong with their baby; Jeanie treats a suicidal woman who reveals a surprising secret; and Greene learns that Rachel has been lying about her health.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: In the Season 1 finale, House's ex-girlfriend Stacy arranges for him to examine her husband, who's experiencing unexplained abdominal pain and mood swings. Other doctors say the cause is stress, but Stacy thinks otherwise. She also thinks that she and House might not be over each other.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: In the Season 2 opener ,House battles to save the life of a volatile death-row inmate who collapses in an exercise yard after hearing the "voices" of the four people he murdered. Just getting him to the hospital requires legal gymnastics, and recently rehired hospital lawyer Stacy Warner performs them---without Cuddy's knowledge. Meanwhile, Cameron refuses to believe a young woman's lung-cancer diagnosis.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A child cancer patient hallucinates for no apparent reason, and bravely undergoes numerous procedures to determine the cause---too bravely, House suspects. He thinks her bravery could be a symptom of a brain tumour. Meanwhile, in the clinic, House must deal with a young man who unsuccessfully tried to alter his appearance.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A young handyman working for Cuddy falls from her roof, and his condition worsens in the hospital. Meanwhile, a black clinic patient complains of racism when Foreman gives him a blood-pressure medication targeted to blacks.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A doctor who's famous for his humanitarian work in Africa collapses while giving a presentation in a drug-company boardroom. He assumes he has TB, but House, who (not surprisingly) scoffs at the doctor's mission, suspects that something else is wrong. Meanwhile, an imperious clinic patient doesn't like Foreman's bedside manner and complains to Cuddy about it. Trouble is, Foreman was wearing House's name tag at the time.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A soon-to-graduate Princeton senior complains of shock like sensations just before collapsing while taking part in a frat-party drinking contest. Then, in the hospital, he suddenly becomes incontinent after his father tells him that his mother, who had died 15 years earlier in an auto accident, hadn't been killed by a drunken driver. Meanwhile, House's parents are in the area, and House doesn't want to see them.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A champion bicycle racer has difficulty breathing during a race and collapses. House suspects doping and he's correct. But the guy doesn't respond to treatment. Meanwhile, House and Stacy are already sniping at each other before House confronts her husband, Mark, at his support-group session.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A scuffle with House lands a gay man with AIDS in the hospital, where he provides the disagreeable diagnostician with a medical puzzle. It's a messy one: The man coughs up blood on Cameron, who begins behaving uncharacteristically. Elsewhere, House finds an unusual (though not at all uncharacteristic) way to spend time with Stacy.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: The team suspect foul play when a Marine corporal and amateur race-car driver is involved in a fatal crash. Elsewhere, the US Attorney's office gathers evidence for a Grand Jury indictment appeal in the Garcia case that would extricate the cartel from the city.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: Pride must protect a family member who's engaged to the prime suspect in the ongoing NCIS and FBI cartel case.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: Sebastian goes undercover and Patton employs his gambling skills to help the team trap Garcia.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: Pride investigates a murder on a deep-sea-oil rig, where the team discover a dangerous gas leak that threatens to cause a catastrophic explosion. Elsewhere, Sebastian begins his special-agent training at FLETC.(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: The team search for a group of underground hackers led by Elvis Bertrand after thousands of classified-government files are stolen. Meanwhile, Sebastian joins the team as an NCIS Special Agent.(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: The Charmed Ones are forced to make unusual alliances when preparing for the final battle. Meanwhile, Billie and Christy hope to gain an advantage by tapping into the power of a forbidden artifact, but its effects are unpredictable.(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: In the series finale, Piper races through time hoping to change the outcome of the final showdown. She visits important moments in the Halliwell family history, both past and present, encountering familiar faces who pitch in to help.(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: In the opener, San Francisco sisters become witches, learning that Prue has telekinetic powers, Phoebe can see the future and Piper can stop time.(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.sub-title: I've Got You Under My Skin
programme.desc: Trudeau and Morris hunt for a man who abducts women, unaware he's an evil being who feeds off women's beauty---and has set his sights on a Halliwell sister. Meanwhile, Phoebe uses her powers despite her sisters' disapproval.(n)

programme.title: The Goldbergs
programme.desc: Beverly forbids Adam to see the R-rated movie "Porky's", so Murray encourages his son to break the rules. But Adam's rule-breaking doesn't stop there. Meanwhile, Barry employs the music of Lionel Ritchie in an effort to impress Lainey on Valentine's Day.(n)

programme.title: The Goldbergs
programme.desc: Dana comes to town, but has a hard time mustering up any enthusiasm for a "Weird Al" Yankovic concert Adam wants her to attend, which makes him think their relationship is coming to an end. Meanwhile, Erica and Barry take their newfound knowledge as peer counsellors and apply it to Murray, who they diagnose as depressed.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Hathaway receives her medical exam score and must decide whether to pursue medical school. Meanwhile, Ross tries valiantly to save a 2-year-old boy's life; and Carter catches Dale falsifying a patient's record and considers turning him in.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Jeanie is faced with a dilemma when she agrees to ask Fischer to approve Al for an experimental AIDS-treatment program; Hathaway accuses Ross of preferential treatment in regards to the child of a wealthy businessman; Carter and Benton assist in a kidney transplant operation.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Benton and Carla fear for their baby's life when complications arise and the child is born two months prematurely; Carter rethinks his plans to be a surgeon; and Ross invites Hathaway out for her birthday.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: In the third season finale, Benton and Carla's infant son continues his struggle for life, as his frustrated parents fearfully stand by; Greene suffers from post-traumatic stress stemming from his attack; and Charlie returns.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: In the fourth season premiere, a film crew shooting a documentary on a "typical" day in the ER follows Dr Greene, who's still dealing with the aftereffects of a violent attack.(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Benton breaks in a new surgical resident, Elizabeth Corday, from England; Carter and Del Amico start training two new med students; Greene is surprised when he is served a subpoena; and Benton and Carla name their baby boy.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: Chase misdiagnoses a woman with an ulcer, and flashbacks (told from various points of view) dissect the case as her condition deteriorates. Stacy questions him and House about it following the patient's death and prior to a hospital disciplinary hearing.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: House meets a hard-drinking, quick-thinking woman at an off-track betting parlour just before she has a seizure. Later, at the hospital, she seems strangely unconcerned when Cameron tells her that she has fast-killing pancreatic cancer. Meanwhile, in the wake of Chase's disciplinary hearing, Foreman is temporarily in charge of the unit, but that doesn't mean he'll get a lot of respect from his new underling House.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: While House and Stacy are in Baltimore to defend his billing practices to Medicaid, a famous journalist with substance abuse in his past collapses, hits his head and suddenly can speak only gibberish. Cameron, Chase and Foreman can't agree on a diagnosis. As the patient's condition deteriorates, House is available by phone, but he and Stacy are snowed in at the airport.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 34-year-old supermum is hospitalised after spasms in her arms cause an auto accident. Then she has a stroke. Meanwhile, Stacy and House try to come to grips with their encounter in Baltimore; and Cameron is reluctant to take a test that will determine once and for all if she's HIV positive.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 16-year-old who crashes his ATV suffers severe burns. Then he develops heart trouble and brain dysfunction, and has a seizure as well. Meanwhile, it's payback time for a doctor who ratted out House for cheating in med school 20 years ago: The doc has come up with a migraine therapy House thinks is bogus, and he sets out to prove it---by experimenting on himself.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 15-year-old supermodel collapses on a catwalk after seeing double and inexplicably attacking another model. At the hospital, she has short-term memory loss, and a tox screen finds heroin in her system. But could the drug be masking her illness? Meanwhile, no amount of Vicodin can mask House's worsening leg pain.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A man suffers a seizure, then bacteria attack his heart, and he needs a transplant immediately. But the only potential donor was suffering from a mysterious illness that renders her heart unusable. At least that's what the protocols say. House isn't about to let that---or standard medical ethics---get in his way.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A man stops breathing during rough sex with his wife, then he develops an agonizingly itchy rash, but those symptoms belie his test results. Meanwhile, House diagnoses a Wall Street workaholic with herpes. The man swears he had sex only with his wife, who swears (loudly to Cuddy) that she hasn't been cheating, either. And Wilson, who's soon to be single again, moves in with House. They make an odd couple indeed.(n)
